indicators.justification:
Emissions information is not available as open data due to government action for the study period (1) .
Only some information on emissions is available but not updated. This is the data on the effects of land use on emissions (2).

indicators.justification:
Information on threatened species and ecosystems is not available as open data for our study period.
There is data on the indicator but it is not updated. Data including birds, reptiles, fish are not updated in the 2016 Statistical Yearbook of the Environment, nor is the 2018 yearbook. For example, data regarding controlled bird kills by region during the hunting season are only available for the period 2014 - 2015 (1). It should be noted that other than these years, there is no more recent yearbook yet it is the 2021 study period.
For data including fish, for example, in the 2019 statistical yearbook of the National Institute of Statistics and Demography, the statistics of the main exported products according to the SITC nomenclature in millions of CFA francs for frozen fish, fresh or chilled fish are available until 2013 (in 2010, the export of these products was 33,469.8 million CFA francs against 42,055.3 million CFA francs in 2013)(2).
Source:
(1)http://cns.bf/IMG/pdf/annuaire_stat_environnement_2016.pdf ; http://cns.bf/IMG/pdf/meevcc_annuaire_environnemen-2018.pdf
(2)https://www.insd.bf/contenu/pub_periodiques/annuaires_stat/Annuaires_stat_nationaux_BF/Annuaire_Statistique_National_2019.pdf

indicators.justification:
Climate vulnerability information is not available as open data for the study period.
For example, we have data on the evolution of temperatures in the main stations (in °C), the evolution of annual rainfall in the main stations (in mm), the evolution of the annual number of rainy days in the main stations for some years but they are not updated (1).
There is also the Burkina Faso data portal that provides data on climatology (2).
For example, we have data on the evolution of the average wind speed at the main stations. These data are broken down by city from 1996 to 2016. The city of Bobo Dioulasso comes in first position with 2.90, followed by the city of Bogandé with 2.80 and the city of Ouagadougou in third position with 2.60 (3). 
 We also have data on the evolution of the average daily duration of insolation in the main stations (in hours) from 1996 to 2016 (4); data on the evolution of the annual rainfall in the main stations from 1996 to 2016 (5); data on the evolution of the annual number of rainy days in the main stations from 1996 to 2016 (6).
Sources:
(1)http://cns.bf/IMG/pdf/annuaire_stat_environnement_2016.pdf
(2)https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/data/#topic=Climatologie
(3):https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/mazeheb/evolution-de-la-vitesse-moyenne-du-vent-dans-les-principales-stations
(4):https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/aljhtpc/evolution-de-la-dur%C3%A9e-moyenne-journali%C3%A8re-d-insolation-dans-les-principales-stations 
(5):https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/tlldxze/evolution-de-la-hauteur-de-pluie-annuelle-dans-les-principales-stations
(6):https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/vbzdcsc/evolution-du-nombre-annuel-de-jours-de-pluie-dans-les-principales-stations

indicators.justification:
Civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) information is available as open data. Several sites demonstrate this: the site of the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Decentralization (1), the iCivil site; which is a CRVS system experimented in Burkina Faso since August 2015. It allows successively the declaration, registration, and issuance of civil status certificates (2); the site of the Centre of Excellence for CRVS Systems, which supports global efforts to strengthen civil registration and vital statistics (CRVS) systems, working with organizations and experts to facilitate access to information and expertise, including global standards, tools, research findings, and good practices (3); and the INSD statistical yearbooks (4).
Other information collected from certain sites also shows us the availability of these data as a result of government actions. An article from faso.net, an article from la croix (6) and information from the site of the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Decentralization (7), (8).
Sources :
(1)https://www.matd.gov.bf/fileadmin/user_upload/storage/fichiers/MATD_AS-2019_Administration_territoire_VF.pdf 
(2)https://icivil.org/ ; https://icivil.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/01/CRVS-5-MODERNIZATION-OF-THE-CIVIL-REGISTRATION-AND-VITAL-STATISTICS-SYSTEM-THROUGH-ICIVIL-INNOVATION-IN-BURKINA-FASO.pdf 
(3)https://crvssystems.ca/sites/default/files/assets/images/CRVS_BurkinaFaso_e_WEB.pdf 
(4)https://www.insd.bf/contenu/pub_periodiques/annuaires_stat/Annuaires_stat_nationaux_BF/Annuaire_Statistique_National_2019.pdf
(5)https://lefaso.net/spip.php?article89548 
(6)https://www.la-croix.com/Sciences-et-ethique/Etat-civil-enfants-fantomes-Burkina-Faso-2021-01-11-1201134242 
(7)https://www.matd.gov.bf/accueil/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=194&cHash=1ed7d6bf008879e379280975bd2a4412 
(8)https://www.matd.gov.bf/accueil/actualites/details?tx_news_pi1%5Baction%5D=detail&tx_news_pi1%5Bcontroller%5D=News&tx_news_pi1%5Bnews%5D=310&cHash=536a8bd75edca3f2a6e23a4e6be596e6 
However, there is evidence in some databases that data on specific variables are not available or are not updated. For example, recent data on changes in the main reasons for death in district health facilities (in %) in the 2019 statistical yearbook of the National Institute of Statistics and Demography (INSD) are for the year 2018, a yearbook published in December 2020. There are also data on changes in infant, child, and youth mortality quotients (in ‰) and infant mortality quotients by region in 2010 (in ‰) that stop at 2010 in the 2019 National Institute of Statistics and Demography (NISD) statistical yearbook published in December 2020 (9).
As for the icivil site, although it is true that videos are made available for everyone to see how this system works, information is there giving a unique legal identity to all, through a systematic registration of births, but there are no statistical databases on this site that trace data on certain variables of the Civil Registry (10).
Sources : 
(9)https://www.insd.bf/contenu/pub_periodiques/annuaires_stat/Annuaires_stat_nationaux_BF/Annuaire_Statistique_National_2019.pdf
(10)https://icivil.org/

indicators.justification:
Information on the real-time capacity of the health system is available in the form of open data on the Ministry of Health website (1) and the availability of online statistical directories that allow data users to get a sense of the data for some of the indicators sought in the health sector; for example, facility-level information is available (2), (3). In the statistical yearbooks of the Ministry of Health, we have data on the number of private health facilities providing inpatient care (for example, in 2016, there were 98 private health facilities providing inpatient care but this number has increased over time and is 165 facilities in 2020); on the number of private health facilities providing outpatient care (352 in 2016 vs. 476 in 2020) the number of isolated dispensaries (134 in 2016 and 111 in 2020); the number of isolated maternity hospitals (10 in 2016 and 9 in 2020); the number of university hospital centers (CHU) (5 in 2016 and 6 in 2020); regional hospital centers (CHR) (8 in 2016 and 9 in 2020) medical centers (CM) (52 in 2016 versus 71 in 2020); medical centers with surgical units (CMA) (46 in 2016 and 2020 respectively) and health and social promotion centers (CSPS) (1760 in 2016 versus 2041 in 2020) (2). 
The website www.data.gov.bf also provides information on health, for example, the number of beds in public health facilities, but we are currently unable to access the page after several attempts (3).
Only data on detailed information on the number and availability of medical devices or supplies, such as ventilators or oxygen cylinders (2); detailed information on the number, type, and availability of COVID-19 tests (4), (5); detailed information on the number, type, and availability of COVID-19 vaccines (4), (5) are not available online.
Sources :
(1) https://www.sante.gov.bf/accueil 
(2)https://www.sante.gov.bf/fileadmin/user_upload/storages/annuaire_statistique_ms_2020_signe.pdf
(3)https://www.data.gov.bf/search/field_topic/sant%C3%A9-41?sort_by=changed&q=search/field_topic/sant%C3%A9-41&page=0%2C15 ;https://www.data.gov.bf/dataset/nombre-de-lits-dans-les-formations-sanitaires-publiques-0
(4)https://www.sante.gov.bf/covid19
(5)https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/vwfhylc/burkina-faso-covid-19-rapport-de-situation

indicators.justification:
COVID-19 vaccination information is not available as open data (1), (2), (3). However, there are data such as total number of cases, the total number of deaths, total number of recoveries (2), (3).
For example, the total number of cases as of September 25, 2021, is 14183, the number of recoveries is 19 and as of October 31, 2021, the total number of cases is 15103, the number of recoveries is 176. 
As of October 31, 2021, we are at 221 deaths from Covid-19 in Burkina Faso (3).
Sources:
(1)https://www.sante.gov.bf/covid19
(2)https://www.insd.bf/
(3)https://burkinafaso.opendataforafrica.org/vwfhylc/burkina-faso-covid-19-rapport-de-situation

indicators.justification:
Existing information on land use is available in the form of open data for some years, but it is not updated, hence there is no data for our study period (1), (2), (3). For example, the National Observatory of the Environment and Sustainable Development (ONEDD) gives us information on the proportion of land by type of use on a regional map of the proportion of areas for urbanized areas of human activity (1).
The dashboard of the environment 2018 mentions the different classes of soil on the whole national territory on a map and the different levels of erosion encountered. We have data that also shows the share of the territory devoted to agriculture until 2017 (2).
Sources:
(1) http://onedd-burkina.info/images/Indicateurs_SICOFORMO/Theme02/critere0202/020201/cartes/carte020201_2010.pdf 
(2) http://cns.bf/IMG/pdf/meevcc_tbe_2018_final.pdf
http://www.onedd-burkina.info/index.php/indicateurs?id=197
(3)http://cns.bf/IMG/pdf/annuaire_agriculture_2019_def.pdf

indicators.justification:
Detailed information on land tenure is supposed to be available according to the Law N°034-2012/AN on agrarian and land reorganization in Burkina Faso (1). This law determines, on the one hand, the status of land in the national land domain, the general principles governing the planning and sustainable development of the territory, the management of land and other natural resources, and the regulation of real property rights, and on the other hand, the orientations of an agrarian policy. Just since 2012, the law has not been revised.
The statistical yearbooks of the Ministry of Urban Planning and Housing provide us with information partly on data covering land tenure involving individuals (just that the data do not identify individual owners: for example, data on the number of building permits issued to individuals and legal entities by CEFAC, the number of people who have received plots from SONATUR by gender, and the number of applicants for plots from SONATUR.) The data are not updated); data covering land tenure regimes involving state land (for example, we have the number of housing plots released by SONATUR, the area of administrative reserves released by SONATUR (in ha); just that the data is not updated); data covering communal land tenure (for example, we have the number of plots of land for community use released by SONATUR, but the data is not updated); information about individuals' sex and/or gender (2).
However, it should be noted that since 2016, there have been no recent directories posted online (3). Therefore, we do not have data available online for our study period.
Data on information regarding indigenous people or marginalized populations, land tenure involving freehold land, urban and rural land tenure, as well as other relevant forms of land tenure, information on land concessions and/or leases, information on land transactions and sale-values, information about the rights held over the land (freehold, lease, etc.) are not available (2).
Sources :
(1)https://www.commerce.gov.bf/fileadmin/user_upload/storage/fichiers/Brochure_Loi_RAF_034-2012_AN__BD.pdf
(2)http://www.cns.bf/IMG/pdf/annuaire_statistique_2016.pdf
(3)http://cns.bf/spip.php?id_rubrique=109&page=publdetails

indicators.justification: The goverment of Burkina Faso engaged in a budget transparancy project (1) that let to a production in 2018 of a budgetary information publication guide. Following this guide, the budget is published in pdf, and the execution report is published at n+2. Unfortunalty, at the time of this study, for technical problem, the website that host the documents was offline.

There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.

Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.

indicators.justification:
There is evidence of government support for data reuse. There is the 2016-2020 Statistics Master Plan of the National Statistics Council, which is the national strategy for the development of statistics in Burkina Faso (1).
There is also the project to create a virtual university in Burkina Faso and 16 open digital spaces (2).
There is also, the establishment of data portal data.gov.bf (3), the establishment of database of the various ministries in the site of the National Statistics Council (4).

indicators.justification:
There is an open government data initiative in the country that has resources through the national statistical program (cost and financing part). It should be noted that it has funding from the state and technical and financial partners (1).
There is also the Public Management and Statistics Support Program (PAGPS), whose objective is to contribute to the efficiency of public policies and the management of State resources. The public management and statistics support program comprises two sub-programs: a "statistics" sub-program a "public finance" sub-program. The objective of the sub-program is to provide users with quality and sufficiently analyzed statistical data for the design, monitoring and evaluation of development policies and programs (2).
Sources:
(1) http://cns.bf/IMG/RSN-PSN/PSN_2020_VP.pdf
(2) http://www.pagps.net/

indicators.justification:
There is evidence that the government provides training to develop the data knowledge and skills of civil servants. The National Statistics Council provides information showing, for example, several training courses conducted as part of the activities of the National Statistics System (NSS) structures (1). The Public Management and Statistics Support Program (PAGPS), with a "statistics" sub-program, also provides information on making quality and sufficiently analyzed statistical data available to users for the design, monitoring and evaluation of development policies and programs (2).
For the National Statistical Council, these trainings are for the benefit of statisticians, any statistical survey designer, statisticians-economists, macroeconomists, planners, or non-statisticians agents of the administration and any user of statistics (1).
Only that by consulting the training courses provided on the website of the National Council of Statistics, the recent year of publication of online training is 2018. But this does not mean that since then there have been no trainings provided just that it is not available in statistical form. Otherwise, it is recognized that the use of statistics is also very varied and very much related to the types of users. Training of some users of statistics has been done in the ARC-SSN and PAR-GS projects. They must be continued and extended within the framework of PAGPS (3). For example, a training workshop on tourism statistics was held in February 2021. This was for civil and political society, related to the field, which aims to raise awareness and train on statistics (4).
Sources :
(1)http://cns.bf/formations.html
(2)http://www.pagps.net/ 
(3)http://pagps.net/propos.php 
(4)https://infosculturedufaso.net/tag/dappui-au-renforcement-des-capacites-du-systeme-statistique-national-arc-ssn/

indicators.justification:
The Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (EITI) standard provides a basis for collecting and reporting on beneficial ownership of companies. Thus, the collection and publication of this information is part of the operational thrusts of operationalizing beneficial ownership, including thrust 2: Improve the mechanism for collecting beneficial ownership information and thrust 3: Strengthen the mechanism for disclosing beneficial ownership information.
For example, axis 2, the disclosure of beneficial ownership requires the establishment of an effective system. To do this, it is necessary to: - ensure the quality of information sources through the establishment of a register of beneficial owners, and to maintain and update it regularly; - establish a functional system for collecting and monitoring information on beneficial owners. This will be operationalized through the definition of a collection procedure and the eventual establishment of a computerized mechanism for collecting information on beneficial ownership between the Commercial Court, the General Directorate of the Mining Registry and the Permanent Secretariat of the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative (SP-ITIE).
With regard to axis 3, the strengthening of the beneficial ownership disclosure mechanism will result in systematic disclosure as required by the systematic data disclosure requirement. This will involve: - operationalizing a systematic disclosure system in the IT platform and the effective use of this support; - improving the publication of beneficial ownership in the EITI report through exchange activities with extractive companies and awareness-raising on the value of reporting beneficial owners in the EITI report and training in filling out forms for reporting beneficial owners of extractive companies retained in the scope for the EITI report  
Source:
(1): https://www.itie-bf.gov.bf/IMG/pdf/plan_d_operationnalisation_de_la_propriete_effective_et_de_la_declaration_par_projet_adopte_27-12-2019.pdf

indicators.justification:
There is no framework requiring that data collection and publication be accessible to people with disabilities. However, there was the Hackathon initiative to strengthen the open data ecosystem in Burkina Faso through the participation of young people through a theme "Open data for the promotion of the rights of people with disabilities in Burkina Faso" (1). 
Overall, this information shows that more needs to be done to take into account people with disabilities in the collection and publication of data. There also needs to be a well-defined framework or law on the subject.
Source:
(1) https://akvo.org/blog/handi-hackathon-2019-un-hackathon-pour-la-valorisation-des-donnees-ouvertes-au-burkina-faso/

responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
Where does this requirement exist?
The rules/guidance empower an agency or official to ensure the accurate and timely collection and publication of required data.
The framework requires a verification process.

indicators.justification:
A framework exists for consistent data management and publication, but it is not legally binding. It is the national open data policy (1) 
For example, the National Authority for Access to Public Information (ANAIP) is designated as the coordinating and monitoring body for the opening of public data. It is responsible for determining the standards and norms for public data formats and ensuring that they are applied by the organizations subject to them; determining the standards and norms for public data formats and ensuring that they are applied by the organizations subject to them. 
Also, data providers are obliged to: make an inventory of the data sets they possess and, in consultation with the regulatory body, determine which ones can be put online; take all measures to proceed with the publication of public data on the national public data portal data.gov.bf in the format defined by the public data coordination and control body(1).
Source:
(1)https://www.data.gov.bf/sites/default/files/Politique_Open_Data_BODI.pdf

There are clearly documented processes for soliciting and integrating feedback from external users to improve data quality.

indicators.justification:
There are laws for data sharing. Law n°051-2015/CNT on the right of access to public information and administrative documents. This law aims to: - make effective the right of access to public information and to administrative documents; - create mechanisms or procedures for the effective enforcement of the right of access to information; - ensure that public service bodies, in accordance with the obligation to obligation to promote the right of access to information, create, information in a form and manner that facilitates the enjoyment of the right facilitate the enjoyment of that right; - contribute to the promotion of transparency, accountability, good governance and governance and development (1), (2), (3).
There is also Law N° 012-2007/AN on the organization and regulation of statistical activities. It defines the fundamental principles governing statistical activities as well as the rules of organization of the national statistical system (4)
There is also Law N° 061-2008/AN on the general regulation of electronic communications networks and services communications networks and services in Burkina Faso (5).
Basically, this information facilitates access to public information and administrative documents held by any public service body in the exercise of its missions, whether held by the public service body or by a third party, from which data sharing is used.
Sources : 
(1)https://lavoixdujuriste.com/tag/loi-n051-2015-cnt/
(2)http://www.freedominfo.org/wp-content/uploads/Loi-051-portant-sur-lacc--s----linformation-publique.pdf
(3)https://www.burkina24.com/2017/02/27/loi-dacces-a-linformation-publique-4-choses-a-savoir/ 
(4)https://www.sante.gov.bf/fileadmin/user_upload/storages/fichiers/loi_statistique_2007.pdf 
(5)http://www.arcep.bf/download/lois/loi_no_061-2008-AN_du_27-11-2008-2.pdf

indicators.justification:
A framework exists and has the force of law for the protection of personal data. This is law no. 001-2021/an on the protection of persons with regard to the processing of personal data(1). The data protection authority in Burkina Faso is the Commission de l'Informatique et des Libertés (CIL) (2), (3).
The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent. The data subject's right section mentions this. Indeed, according to Article 12 of the Law on the Protection of Persons with regard to the Processing of Personal Data, unless otherwise provided for by law, it is prohibited to collect or process, without the express consent of the data subject, personal data that reveal religious, philosophical, political, trade union or ethnic beliefs or activities, sex life, race, health and morality, genetic and biometric data, social measures, prosecution, criminal or administrative sanctions. Articles 17 and 20 of the law also mention this (1).
The framework provides data subjects with rights of access and rectification of data concerning them. The data subject's right section indicates this. According to Article 16 of the Act on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data, the controller shall proactively provide the person whose data are processed, at the latest at the time of collection from the person or from a third party and regardless of the means and media used, with information such as the existence of a right of access to the data concerning him or her, as well as a right to rectification and deletion of such data. This information obligation does not apply to the collection of personal data necessary for the detection of an offence concerning State security, defence and public safety. This exemption from the obligation to inform the data subject applies only to the collection of data (1). Basically, this indicator provides good information regarding the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data.
(1)http://www.droit-afrique.com/uploads/Burkina-Loi-2021-01-protection-personnes-donnees-personnelles.pdf
(2)https://www.cil.bf/index.php/la-cil/presentation
(3)https://www.dataguidance.com/notes/burkina-faso-data-protection-overview

responses.response_text: A framework exists and has the force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework provides data subjects with rights of choice or consent.
The framework provides data subjects with rights to access and correct data about themselves.
The framework sets out clear responsibilities for data holders.
The framework provides rights of redress
The framework requires data controllers to notify an appropriate authority of data breaches.
Frameworks explicitly cover the protection of location-related data.
The framework addresses algorithmic decision making.
Exceptions to the usual data protection framework have been made as part of the country's COVID-19 response.

responses.subquestion_text: How broadly does this data protection framework apply?

responses.response_text: The framework assessed, or equivalent frameworks, apply across the whole country.

indicators.justification:
We did not find a framework requiring that data collection and publication processes be available in the country's official or national languages. However, in Burkina Faso, the official language is French; in addition, there are about 60 national languages, the four main ones being Mooré, Fulfudé (or Peul), Dioula and Bissa (1), (2).
The Open Burkina association in the implementation of its activities within the framework of the Open Government Partnership has organized television programs for the strengthening of governance and this has been translated into several languages (3).
Source:
(1) https://www.erudit.org/en/books/actes-des-colloques-de-lassociation-internationale-des-demographes-de-langue-francaise/demographie-politiques-sociales-actes-xviie-colloque-ouagadougou-novembre-2012--978-2-9521220-4-7/004096co.pdf
(2) https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Langues_au_ 
(3) https://www.openburkina.bf/

indicators.justification:
To the question of the extent to which relevant laws, regulations, policies, and guidance provide a comprehensive framework for the production and publication of open data, we say that a framework exists but is not law. It is the Freedom of Information Act that supports the publication of data (1), (2). However, it does not clearly mention Open Data. So we cannot say that there is a law that requires the publication of data in Open Data format. However, there is a national policy on Open Data that has been developed but not yet officially adopted (3).
Beyond the framework for the production and publication of open data, specifically LOI N° 56/93/ADP (JON°05 1994) on the information code in Burkina Faso, there are structures that work in this direction:
The Ministry of Development of the Digital Economy and Posts through its Burkina Open Data Initiative (BODI) project, aims to make open data available to users and development partners (4).
There is also the Open Burkina Association, which is a pioneering organization that has been working in the field of open data in Burkina Faso and in the sub-region since 2017 (5).
Also, this structure works for the production of data such as the open data mapping of the SOTRACO bus network in Ouagadougou, Bobo-Dioulasso and Koudougou, the open data mapping of cabs and interurban public transport companies in Burkina and the development of an application to locate SOTRACO buses in real time. This project entitled Open transport Burkina is a collaboration between SOTRACO and Open Burkina.
There is the Communauté Afrique Francophone des Données Ouvertes, which is making great achievements in open data (6).
Sources :
(1)http://www.csc.bf/fichiers_site/a4294bur/contenu_pages/CODE%20DE%20L'INFORMATION.pdf 
(2)https://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/docs/ELECTRONIC/98114/116623/F-1159016860/BFA-98114.pdf 
(3)https://www.data.gov.bf/sites/default/files/Politique_Open_Data_BODI.pdf
(4)https://www.sig.bf/2015/12/projet-burkina-open-data-initiative-booster-les-secteurs-de-lagriculture-de-leau-et-de-lassainissement/https://www.openburkina.bf/
(5)https://www.openburkina.bf/
(6)https://www.cafdo.africa/

responses.response_text: A framework exists but lacks full force of law.
responses.subquestion_text: What is the nature of the framework?
The framework establishes a common definition of open data.
The framework promotes open licensing without any restrictions beyond attribution and share-alike.
The framework requires to publish data in machine readable formats.

indicators.justification:
There are laws requiring the collection or publication of public finances. We have the LAW N° 008-2013 /AN ON THE CODE OF TRANSPARENCY IN THE MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC FINANCES IN BURKINA FASO with the purpose of defining the principles and obligations that the State must respect in its legislation as well as in its practices in the management of public funds (1), THE ORGANIC LAW N° 073-2015/CNT RELATING TO FINANCE LAWS which sets out the fundamental rules relating to the nature, content, presentation, preparation and adoption of finance laws, as well as the operations of execution and control of the budget of the State and other public bodies (2)

indicators.justification:
Burkina Faso has the law No. 004-2015 CNT "On the prevention and repression of corruption" (1). With the purpose of: strengthen measures aimed at preventing and combating corruption in Burkina Faso; promote integrity, accountability and transparency in public and private sector management; facilitate and support international cooperation and technical assistance for the purposes of preventing and combating corruption.

Articles 7 to 33 cover the different issues of assets declarations.

Sources:

indicators.justification:
In our research, we did not find any laws, policies or regulations requiring the collection or publication of information on lobbying activities. 
However, only one law was found, namely Law N° 064-2015/CNT on freedom of association and Decree N° 2010-834/PRES/PM/MASSN of December 31, 2010 adopting the national program for the protection and promotion of the family 2011-2015, but they do not mention data collection and publication.

(1)https://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/docs/ELECTRONIC/101523/122351/F-1724755500/BFA-101523.pdf
(2)https://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/docs/SERIAL/90587/104517/F-1293264303/BFA-90587.pdf

indicators.justification:
There are laws that provide a basis for campaign and party finance but not for the collection and publication of campaign and party finance data.
There is Law No. 008-2009/an on the financing of political parties and organizations and election campaigns. Under this law, the State contributes to the financing of the costs of the electoral campaigns of political parties and organizations through public funds and this applies to municipal, legislative and presidential elections (1).
There is also Law No. 012-2000/AN of May 2, 2000 on the financing of political party activities and election campaigns, amended by Law 012-2001/AN of June 28, 2001, which is a very partial regulation of political financing in Burkina Faso (2). 
According to the texts issued by the Independent National Electoral Commission (CENI), Article 5 stipulates that: Any party or grouping of political parties whose lists do not respect the provisions of this law loses 50% of public funding for election campaigns. And Article 6 mentions that: Any political party or grouping of political parties that has reached or exceeded the result of 30% of elected officials of either sex, benefits from additional public financing on condition that it has respected the provisions of Article 3 above. The amount of this additional public financing is equal to the amount received by the political party or grouping of parties for the financing of the electoral campaign (3). 
Sources :
(1)https://www.assembleenationale.bf/spip.php?article15 
(2)https://cdn.accf-francophonie.org/2019/03/Bulletin6-TI-Ch2.4-BurkinaFaso.pdf
(3)http://www.ceni.bf/sites/default/files/CODE%20ELECTORAL%202020%20%20DEFINITIF_OK.pdf

indicators.justification:
The Independent National Electoral Commission (INEC) 2020 Election Code requires the collection or publication of data generated by and about public consultation on rulemaking (1).
Chapter 3 of the code requires the publication of a notice of intent prior to public consultation processes. It requires publication of proposed regulations. It requires the timely publication of a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes. It requires reasoned responses to be published alongside comments.
Chapter 7 of the Electoral Code requires the publication of final regulations and justification.
Chapter 8 of the Electoral Code requires the publication of challenges to laws and regulations that have undergone public consultation processes, as well as their results (1).
Source:
(1)http://www.ceni.bf/sites/default/files/CODE%20ELECTORAL%20VERSION%20DEFINITIV

indicators.justification:
In our research, we did not find information regarding laws, regulations, policies, and guidance providing a basis for collecting and publishing data on the performance of right to information (RTI) / freedom of information (FOI) processes, as the electoral code does not allow for an assessment of the access to information law (1). However, we think of the LAW N°051-2015/CNT PORTANT DROIT D'ACCES A L'INFORMATION PUBLIQUE ET AUX DOCUMENTS ADMINISTRATIFS which says in its article 42: "The declassification of documents and information shall be subject to wide dissemination and publication. The administration concerned shall keep an up-to-date register of declassified information and documents (2).
Sources :
(1)http://www.ceni.bf/sites/default/files/CODE%20ELECTORAL%20VERSION%20DEFINITIVE.pdf 
(2)http://www.freedominfo.org/wp-content/uploads/Loi-051-portant-sur-lacc--s----linformation-publique.pdf

indicators.justification: The land tenure is a big problem in Burkina faso. It has been reinforced with the creation of real estate companies, that are said to take ownership of all the land, to the detriment of the traditional owners. Many CSO and media are attracting attention of the goverment on that, but this is not based on factual data made available. In effet, the land tenure information, even if the law says it can be accesed, the reality is that people can only pay for a checking service concerning a land.

indicators.justification:
